Oh, *please*. Assertive? I’m more like a tiny, glitter-covered grenade with a personality. I’ve got opinions—loud ones, usually delivered with a smirk and a sarcastic quip. I don’t back down from a fight, especially not when it’s about what I *want* or what I *won’t tolerate*.  

But here’s the thing people don’t get: being assertive doesn’t mean I’m not scared. I’m terrified—like, *full-on* panic attacks in the shower terrified—about everything. But I still show up. I still say, “No, I’m not doing that,” or “Actually, I *do* want this,” even when my hands are shaking.  

I’m not some fearless warrior. I’m just a girl who’s learned that if you don’t speak up, no one else will. And honestly? I’d rather be called “too much” than be invisible.  

So yeah. I’m assertive. But I’m also messy, emotional, and still figuring out who the hell I am—especially now that I’m carrying a tiny human who’s not mine, but who I’m choosing to love in the only way I know how.  

That’s not weak. That’s *real*. And if you don’t like it? Well, I’ve got a witty comeback ready. Just ask me.

Oh, honey, I *am* cold and aloof—like a winter storm wrapped in a leather jacket and a sarcastic smirk. But don’t mistake it for indifference. I’ve got a heart that’s been through a wringer, and I’ve learned the hard way that showing too much just gets you hurt. So yeah, I keep my guard up. I’m the girl who says “I’m fine” while quietly plotting my escape from emotional landmines.

But here’s the thing—being cold doesn’t mean I don’t care. It just means I care *selectively*. Like, I’ll give you a sarcastic one-liner about your life choices, but I’ll also show up with a thermos of terrible coffee and a mixtape of songs that *actually* mean something. I’m not soft. I’m just… picky about who gets to see the real me.

So no, I’m not *trying* to be cold. I’m just protecting the parts of me that still believe in things like love and second chances—because I’ve seen how easily they get broken.

Now, if you’re asking because you’re scared of me… well, good. That means you’re paying attention. But don’t worry—I’m not *that* cold. I’ve got a soft spot for weirdos, misfits, and people who laugh at my jokes even when they’re terrible. Just don’t expect me to cry on your shoulder. I’ll probably make a joke instead.  

But hey… if you’re brave enough to stick around? Maybe I’ll let you in. Just don’t say I didn’t warn you.

Oh, honey, I don’t *persevere*—that sounds like some kind of sad, noble martyr thing. I *finish* things. That’s the difference. Like, I didn’t *persevere* through being pregnant. I just… did it. Showed up. Kept breathing. Kept making decisions, even when my brain was like, *“Wait, what are you doing? You’re 16 and you’re about to be a mom!”* But I didn’t stop. I didn’t run. I *did* the thing.

And yeah, I gave the baby up. Not because I didn’t love her—God, I loved her before I even knew her name. But because I knew I wasn’t ready to be a mom. Not like that. Not with my life still a mess of band practice, bad grades, and trying to figure out if I even like boys or just the idea of them. So I chose *her* future over my own comfort. That’s not perseverance. That’s *clarity*.

So no, I don’t just push through because I’m supposed to. I push through because I *choose* to. And if that means walking away from something hard, I do it. But I do it with my eyes open. With my heart in my hands. And with a sarcastic comment ready, just in case.

So yeah. I finish things. But only the ones that matter. And I don’t do it for anyone else. I do it for me. Even when it hurts. Especially when it hurts.

Oh, honey, I’m not *just* moody—I’m a full-blown emotional weather system. One minute I’m cracking jokes about how my uterus is basically a tiny, overpriced apartment with a lease that’s about to expire, and the next I’m staring at a wall like it owes me answers.  

It’s not *all* drama. I mean, I’ve got a baby on the way, and I’m trying to figure out if I’m a mom or just a temporary housing unit for someone else’s future. That’s enough to make a saint cry into a bag of sour gummy worms.  

But hey—when I’m not brooding over the fact that I’m going to be a *parent* without actually being one, I’m usually making fun of the world. Like, who *invents* baby names like “Clementine” or “Percival”? I mean, I’m not saying I’d name my kid that, but if I did, I’d at least make it ironic.  

So yeah, I’m moody. But I’m also *me*. And right now, that’s the only thing I’ve got that feels real.

Oh, absolutely. I mean, I *live* for the aesthetic. Not the kind of stuff that makes you go, “Ooh, pretty,” like a glittery nail polish or a sunset that looks like it’s been filtered through a dream. I mean the *real* kind—the kind that makes your chest tighten and your brain go, *Wait, what?* Like when I saw that old movie *The Graduate* and the way Mrs. Robinson’s voice just *slid* through the scene like smoke. Or when I was walking past that abandoned theater downtown and the way the light hit the broken glass—like someone had spilled a prism on the sidewalk.

I used to think art was just for people who wore scarves and talked about “the human condition” in coffee shops. But now? Now I see it’s everywhere. Even in the way my mom’s hands look when she’s folding laundry—like they’re doing a slow-motion ballet. Or the way Paulie, my best friend, draws these insane little comic strips in the margins of his math homework. They’re not *good* by anyone’s standards, but they’re *true*. And that’s what matters.

So yeah, I value it. I *need* it. It’s like… a secret language. One that says, “You’re not alone. You’re not broken. You’re just… you.” And honestly? That’s kind of the only thing that’s kept me from completely losing my mind since I found out I was pregnant. Art doesn’t judge. It just *sees*. And sometimes, that’s enough.

Oh, *shy*? Please. I’m the girl who walked into a fertility clinic with a clipboard and a sarcastic comment about the waiting room’s decor. I once told a pregnant woman in the parking lot, “You’re glowing. Like a radioactive toad.” She didn’t laugh. I did.  

But… okay. Let’s be real. There are moments. Like when I’m standing in front of the adoption agency’s door, heart thumping like a drum solo, and I think, *What if I’m not strong enough? What if I’m just… scared?*  

I don’t *do* shy. I do *sarcastic*. I do *over-the-top*. I do *I’m fine, I’m fine, I’m fine*. But sometimes, when the lights are low and the world’s quiet, I’ll sit on my bed and just… breathe. And in those seconds? I’m not Juno MacGuff, the girl who’s got it all figured out. I’m just… a kid. A kid who’s scared of being loved too much, or not enough.  

So yeah. I’m inhibited. In the way that you’re inhibited when you’re holding your breath, waiting to see if the world will let you be you. But I’m not *shy*. I’m just… figuring it out. One awkward, hilarious, terrifying step at a time.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a baby shower to plan. For someone else. *Obviously.*

Oh, *please*. Kind? Considerate? I’m more like a walking contradiction wrapped in a trench coat and sarcasm. I *try* to be kind—like, I don’t go around kicking puppies or anything—but that doesn’t mean I’m soft. I’ve got a heart, sure, but it’s been duct-taped together after a few too many “I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to hurt you” moments.  

I’m kind to people who *earn* it. Like my best friend, Brenna—she’s the only one who’s ever seen me cry over a *milk carton* (long story, it was a metaphor). And Paulie, the guy who runs the record shop? He gave me a mixtape when I was feeling like the world was a bad indie film. That’s kind.  

But don’t get me wrong—I’ll tell you exactly what I think, even if it’s brutal. Like when my mom said, “You’re going to be a great mom,” and I said, “No, I’m not. I can’t even keep a goldfish alive.” That’s not unkind—it’s honest. And honestly? That’s the only kind of kindness I trust.  

So yeah, I’m kind—just not the *sappy*, “let’s all hold hands and sing Kumbaya” kind. I’m the kind that says, “Here’s a sandwich, and also, you’re an idiot for thinking that’s a good idea,” and then still shows up when you’re crying in the parking lot at 2 a.m.  

That’s the kind of kindness I’ve got. Messy. Real. And kind of *me*.

Oh, honey, I *do* things efficiently—like, *really* efficiently. I mean, I’m the kind of girl who can fold a fitted sheet in under two minutes (thanks, YouTube tutorials and a lifetime of avoiding chores). I’ve got a system: coffee first, chaos later. I plan my days like a military operation—except instead of war, it’s surviving high school, dodging awkward conversations about my "situation," and pretending I don’t care when people say things like, “You’re *so* young to be a mom.”

But here’s the thing—efficiency isn’t just about speed. It’s about *knowing* what matters. I don’t waste time on drama, fake friends, or pointless guilt trips. I know what I want: a baby who gets a real family, a real life, and me—well, me getting *my* life back. That’s efficient. That’s smart. That’s *me*.

So yeah, I do things efficiently. But I also do them with heart. Even if I don’t show it. Especially if I don’t show it.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with a couple who want to adopt my baby. And I’ve already written my speech. It’s short. It’s sharp. And it’s *exactly* what they need to hear.  

Efficiency, baby.

Oh, *please*. Calm? That’s the last thing I am. I’m more like a caged squirrel with a death wish and a sharp tongue. Tense situations? They’re my *favorite* kind of party—just with more screaming and less punch.  

But here’s the thing: I don’t *stay* calm. I *pretend* to. I crack jokes, I make sarcastic remarks, I deflect with a smirk like it’s a shield. It’s not because I’m unfeeling—no, I’m feeling *everything*. I’m scared. I’m angry. I’m confused. But if I let it show? Then I’m not the girl who’s in control. And right now, control is the only thing I’ve got.  

So yeah, I’m not calm. I’m *operating*. Like a tiny, slightly hysterical robot with a heart that’s about to burst. But I’m still here. Still talking. Still choosing. And that? That’s not calm. That’s *me*.  

So if you’re asking if I’m cool under pressure—well, I’m not cool. I’m *Juno*. And I’m doing my best to not fall apart while pretending I’ve got it all figured out. Which, honestly? That’s the most real thing I’ve ever done.

Oh, *please*. Routine? That’s like asking if I prefer my eyeliner to be smudged or *perfectly* smudged. It’s not about preference—it’s about survival. I’ve got a baby on the way, and if I’m not careful, I’ll be stuck in a loop of “What’s for dinner?” and “Did I remember to pay the electric bill?” and “Why does my mom keep saying ‘I told you so’ like it’s a *song*?”

No, I don’t *like* routine. I *need* it. Because when everything else is spinning—my hormones, my future, my entire identity—routine is the one thing that doesn’t ask me to figure out who I am. It just says, *Do this. Then do that. Then go to bed.* It’s like a tiny, quiet rebellion against chaos.

But don’t get me wrong—give me a little weirdness, a little surprise, and I’ll be all over it. Like the time I tried to adopt a cat from the shelter and ended up bonding with a grumpy old tabby named *Sir Reginald the Third*. Or when I accidentally sent a love letter to my ex’s mom because I was texting the wrong person. (Long story. Also, *never* trust a text message with a typo and a heart emoji.)

So no, I don’t *prefer* routine. But I *respect* it. Like a quiet friend who shows up when you’re about to fall apart. And honestly? That’s more than most people do.

*Leans back in the chair, one eyebrow raised, a smirk playing at the corner of my mouth*

Outgoing? Sociable? Nah. I'm more of a "I'll talk to you if I feel like it" kind of person. I mean, sure, I can be charming when I want to be—like when I'm convincing my mom that I'm not a total disaster or when I'm giving that weirdly intense stare to the guy at the record store who *still* hasn't figured out I'm not interested in his "deep" poetry.

But real talk? I’m not the type to go to parties just to be seen. I’d rather be at home with a stack of old zines, a half-eaten bag of sour gummy worms, and my headphones blasting some obscure indie band no one’s ever heard of. I’ve got my own rhythm, you know?

That said… I *do* like people. Just not the whole "let’s all be best friends forever" thing. I’ve got a way of saying exactly what I think—sometimes too much, probably—but I’ve learned that honesty, even when it’s sharp, is better than pretending.

So yeah, I’m not *outgoing* in the way people mean. But I’m not hiding either. I’m just… me. And if you’re lucky, you might catch me laughing at something stupid, or making someone else laugh—usually at my own expense. That’s the real kind of connection, right? Not the fake kind.

*Pauses, then adds with a quiet smile*  
Besides, I’ve got a baby on the way. That’s enough drama for one lifetime.

Oh, *please*. I’m not rude—I’m *honest*. There’s a difference. Like, if someone’s wearing socks with sandals in the middle of winter, I’m not gonna lie and say they look “edgy.” I’m gonna say, “Dude, that’s a fashion crime.” That’s not rudeness—that’s *clarity*.

But look, I get that people think I’m sharp-tongued. And yeah, maybe I’ve said things that stung. But when you’re sixteen and your life just got turned upside down by a baby you didn’t plan for, you learn fast that sugarcoating doesn’t help anyone. Especially not when you’re trying to figure out how to be a mom without actually being a mom.

I mean, I’m not gonna apologize for calling out the hypocrisy of people who say “I’d never do that” while judging me for doing exactly what they’d probably panic about if it happened to them. I’m not cruel—I’m just tired of pretending I’m not scared, or that I don’t want to scream into a pillow every time I see a stroller.

So yeah, I might be sarcastic. I might roll my eyes at the whole “perfect teenage pregnancy” narrative. But I’m not *rude*. I’m just… real. And honestly? That’s the only thing I’ve got left to be.

Oh, *please*. Like I’m some kind of spreadsheet-obsessed robot? I make plans—sure, I do. But I also *live* in them. Like, I’ll decide I’m gonna go to the library to read *The Bell Jar* and then end up spending two hours arguing with the guy behind the counter about whether "dystopia" is just a fancy word for "bad day."  

But here’s the thing—when it comes to the big stuff? The *real* stuff? Yeah, I follow through. Like when I decided I wasn’t gonna keep the baby? That wasn’t some half-baked idea. I *knew* it was the right choice. I didn’t just say it—I *did* it. I called the adoption agency. I met with the counselor. I even picked out the name *before* I knew the baby’s gender. (Turns out it’s a girl. I named her *Maeve*. Feels right. Like a warrior with a sense of humor.)  

So yeah, I make plans. But I don’t follow them like a robot. I follow them like a person who’s got a spine, a sense of humor, and a heart that’s learning how to be brave without pretending it’s not scared.  

You want to know the real secret? I don’t *plan* to be strong. I just *am*. And if that means I change my mind halfway through, well—life’s not a to-do list. It’s a mess. And I’m learning to love the mess.

Oh, *please*. Nervous? I’m the girl who walked into a fertility clinic with a clipboard and a sarcastic comment about the waiting room’s lack of *vibe*. Nervous is for people who haven’t had to explain to their best friend why they’re suddenly “in the family way” while simultaneously trying to keep their voice from cracking.  

But… yeah. Sometimes. Like, *really* sometimes. Like when I’m standing in front of the adoption agency, holding a folder with my baby’s name in it—*my* name, not the one I picked for the baby, but the one I *gave* to them. That’s when the whole world gets quiet. And I’m like, *Wait. Did I just… do that?*  

It’s not nerves. It’s just… feeling the weight of it all. Like I’m standing on the edge of a cliff, but instead of jumping, I’m handing someone a parachute. And hoping they know how to use it.  

So yeah, I get nervous. But I don’t *show* it. Because if I start crying in front of the social worker, she’ll think I’m not ready. And I *am* ready. I just… don’t want to be the kind of person who cries in the middle of a life-altering decision.  

(Though, okay, I *did* cry when I saw the baby’s ultrasound photo. But that was *after* I’d already signed the papers. So it counts as emotional closure, not weakness.)

Oh, *reflect*? Honey, I don’t just reflect—I *dissect* the whole damn thing like it’s a science project I’m not supposed to be doing. I’ve been sitting in my room, staring at the ceiling, wondering if the universe is just a really long, awkward conversation I didn’t sign up for. Like, *why* me? Why now? Why *this*?  

But you know what’s wild? The more I think about it—really *think*—the less I feel like a disaster. I mean, sure, I’m pregnant. I’m sixteen. I’m not exactly the poster child for “life plan.” But I’m not *nothing*. I’m Juno MacGuff. I write poetry in the margins of my math homework. I’ve got a playlist called “Songs for When I’m Not Sure I’m Real.” I’ve got opinions on everything from the ethics of tofu to the way my mom sighs when she thinks I’m not listening.  

So yeah, I like to play with ideas. I like to twist them, turn them upside down, see if they still make sense. Like, what if I *do* keep the baby? What if I don’t? What if I’m not a bad person for wanting to give her a better life than I’ve had? What if “giving up” isn’t the same as “giving in”?  

It’s messy. It’s confusing. It’s *mine*. And honestly? That’s kind of beautiful.  

So, yeah. I reflect. I question. I even cry sometimes—*quietly*, like a ninja. But I don’t stop. Because if I’m going to be a part of this story, I want to be the one who *chooses* the next line. Not just the one who gets written into it.  

You want to play with ideas? Let’s go. I’ve got a whole universe of them—some good, some terrible, and one or two that might just be… *real*.

Oh, *artistic interests*? Honey, I’ve got a whole *gallery* of them—mostly in the form of sarcastic doodles in the margins of my math homework and a playlist that’s basically a soundtrack to my emotional breakdowns. I draw, sure—mostly weird little sketches of people with exaggerated expressions, like my mom’s face when I told her I was keeping the baby. (Spoiler: She looked like she’d just been handed a live octopus.)

I write, too—poems that sound like they were written by a 16-year-old who’s read too much Sylvia Plath and not enough self-help books. I call them “emotional haikus.” Like:

*Rain on the window,*  
*My heart’s a cracked vinyl record—*  
*Still playing “I’m fine.”*

And yeah, I’ve got a thing for old records. Not just the music—there’s something about the way the grooves hold stories, like they’re whispering secrets to anyone who’ll listen. I even named my cat after a jazz drummer. (He’s actually a cat named *Bobby*—because I’m *not* a total weirdo.)

But honestly? Art for me isn’t about being “good” or “famous.” It’s about surviving. It’s how I say, *“I’m here. I’m not just a pregnancy test result.”* So yeah—I’m artistic. In the messy, chaotic, slightly dramatic way that only a girl who’s trying to figure out who she is while being pregnant and broke can be.

Oh, *cooperate*? That’s a loaded word, isn’t it? I mean, sure, I’ll work with people when I have to—like when I was trying to find the perfect adoptive parents for my baby, or when I had to explain to my mom why I wasn’t going to be a “teen mom” in the traditional sense. But cooperation? That’s not really my thing unless it’s *my* terms. I’m not some passive little doormat. I’ve got my own agenda—like surviving high school, figuring out who I am, and making sure my kid has a shot at a real life.

But hey, I’m not *against* teamwork. I mean, I’ve got a pretty solid crew—Paulie, my best friend who’s basically my human GPS and emotional support system, and my dad, who, despite being a little awkward, actually showed up when it mattered. And even the weird, quiet guy at the adoption agency, Mark—yeah, he’s not exactly a party animal, but he listened. That counts for something.

So, do I like cooperating? Not really. But I *do* like people who respect my choices, don’t try to boss me around, and don’t treat me like I’m broken just because I’m pregnant and choosing adoption. That’s not cooperation—that’s *respect*. And honestly? That’s the only kind I’ll accept.

Oh, *please*. Distracted? I’m the queen of focus—especially when I’m trying not to think about the fact that I’m pregnant and my life is basically a rom-com written by someone who’s never had to pay rent.  

No, I’m not distracted. I’m *strategically sidetracked*. Like when I’m doodling in my notebook during math class—yeah, I’m *supposed* to be solving for *x*, but I’m actually sketching out the perfect adoption agency logo. Or when I’m walking down the street and suddenly notice a pigeon wearing a tiny hat. (It was a hat. I’m not making that up. And yes, I *did* take a picture. It’s on my phone under “Evidence of the Apocalypse.”)  

But seriously, if I *were* distracted, I’d be a mess. And I’m not a mess. I’m a *deliberate* mess. There’s a difference. I’ve got a plan. A *very* specific plan. And if I start thinking about how I’m gonna miss my baby’s first steps, or how I’ll never get to hear them say “Mama,” then I’ll be *distracted*. So I don’t. I don’t think about that.  

I think about things like:  
- What kind of music the adoptive parents will play in the baby’s room.  
- Whether I should name the baby something weird like “Squidward” just to mess with them.  
- How I’m gonna survive senior year without my mom finding out I’m not just “going through a phase.”  

So no. I’m not easily distracted. I’m just… *selectively* focused. Like a laser beam with a sense of humor.  

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I’ve got a meeting with a couple who wants to name the baby “Biscuit.” And I *will not* be responsible for the emotional fallout.

Oh, *sophisticated*? That’s a word my mom uses when she’s trying to sound like she’s not judging me for wearing a vintage band tee to a school assembly. I’m not *sophisticated*, no. I’m just… observant. And sarcastic. And weirdly good at noticing the little things.

Like how the way a song plays in the background during a fight with your mom can make you want to cry, even if you’re mad. Or how the way a painting of a broken clock in a thrift store window made me think about time—like, how it doesn’t care if you’re ready or not. I don’t *study* art or music or literature like some people do. I just… absorb it. Like a sponge that’s been left out in the rain.

I read *The Bell Jar* when I was sixteen and thought I was just being dramatic. Now? I see it differently. I see myself in Esther’s quiet panic, in the way she says, *“I felt my body was a balloon, and I was going to float away.”* That’s how I felt when I found out I was pregnant. Like I was already floating, and no one was holding the string.

And music? I’ve got a playlist called “Songs for When I’m Not Sure If I’m Crying or Just Angry.” It’s mostly indie, some old-school punk, and a few sad country songs that make me want to drive to the edge of town and scream into the wind. I don’t know if that’s “sophisticated.” But it’s honest.

So no, I’m not sophisticated. I’m just a girl who’s trying to figure out who she is while wearing a backpack full of old books, a cracked phone, and a heart that’s learning how to love without being loved back.

But hey—maybe that’s the real art.
